I think I’ll take a walk and look for her

This line tells about the narrator’s next move, but does not solve the ambiguity – it is unclear whether it is a girlfriend that jilted him, or he muses about a girl he hopes to meet at this specific party.

Though I’ve had a drink or two, and I don’t care
 There’s no fun in what I do if she’s not there
 I wonder what went wrong, I’ve waited far too long
 I think I’ll take a walk and look for her

The rhyming  follows the AABA pattern – first, second and forth line in the song rhyme, while the third line’s ending “stands on its own”.

If one listens carefully, in the beginning of the last line, it sounds as if john says “(**If) I think I’ll take….”. It seems as if he was about the flub the lines, starting the last line of the first verse.
Since the take (19th) was the best one, it was left in the final recording.

An in depth discussion of the chord and harmony structure can be found here.
I wonder what went wrong, I’ve waited far too long

A loaded sentence; perhaps the key to explaining the situation the lyricist finds himself.
Something must have gone wrong, which he does not identify, or fails to acknowledge or admit.

The second part may have a clue – “I waited far too long” – to apologize? make up? Maybe even propose?

There’s nothing for me here, so I will disappear
 If she turns up while I’m gone, please let me know

The second part is his thoughts at the party to which he went despite his hesitation.

So – he disappointed his friends and himself, and now he compounds it by quitting.

Rather than having adverse feeling toward the poor guy, one should feel for him, as he exhibits the classic symptoms of a jilted, spurned, exasperated lover.

There’s nothing for me here, so I will disappear
 If she turns up while I’m gone, please let me know

The verses are believed to be John singing both roles (overdubbing) with Paul and George adding the “ooohs” background in the third line.

The lines are thought by many a metaphor for John’s discomfort with the Beatlemania phenomenon, as described in the book “The Songs of John Lennon” –

John indicated in interviews that this was a “deeply personal” song…Recorded by the group on September 29, 1964, right in the midst of Beatlemania, Lennon was finding it difficult to maintain the witty, charming, eve entertaining Beatles' image required at the many parties and the gatherings on the Beatles' expansive social agenda….Lennon and the rest of the Beatles  were always looking for a respite from the chaos of fame…The lyrics from this Lennon song were inspired by these experiences.

Though tonight she’s made me sad
 I still love her
 If I find her, I’ll be glad
 I still love her

Different the the other part’s of the song, this could be considered a bridge, or a chorus.

While John continues to lead, Paul joins with his higher voice for the distinct Beatles harmony.

It’s the second song on the album where the chorus/bridge is not only different, occurring only once climatic peak of the lyrics. It is preceded by “No Reply”, a song that also tells of a jilted lover –

If I were you’d realize that I
Love you more than any other guy
And I’ll forgive the lies that I
Heard before when you gave me no reply

The lyrics add stress to the melancholic, hurt by betrayal, narrator. Interesting introspection by a person who like most, if not all his contemporaries used to betray their spouses/girlfriends while on the road.

I don’t want to spoil the party, so I’ll go
 I would hate my disappointment to show

John Lennon wrote the song (with some contribution by Paul McCartney) during an intensive world wide tour in September, 1964, for their upcoming fourth album to be recorded in September.

The tour was exhausting, and John suffered from depression on different occasions. The song is believed to be inspired by another “sad” party theme mega hit from that era, Lesley Gore’s “It’s My Party”.

Per musicologist Alan Pollack, an authority on the  Beatles –

The extent to which the Beatles were capable of transcending the nominal bounds of the cliché is effectively brought home by comparing our current song with one of the more popular examples in this model done by another roughly contemporaneous “artist”; I’m thinking of the one about “my party” and “I’ll Cry If I Want To” — yes, go ahead and flame me for even thinking about mentioning this one in the same article :-)

Leslie Gore said she would demonstrate demonstrate her disappointment – “ I’ll cry if I want to”…
[Outro]
Very similar to the intro, but with descending crescendo and a “final” note, completing the two bookends for the song.

I don’t want to spoil the party, so I’ll go
 I would hate my disappointment to show

The verse has two parts: Before the party, and then at the party.

A conflicted young lad, apparently the lyricist.
On one hand, he does not want “to spoil the party” for his friends, presumably, but knowing how disappointed he is going to be, how can he not spoil the party? Staying at home seems like the logical decision.

If I find her, I’ll be glad
 I still love her

Many call the song a classic country-rock creation.

One who did “find” the song, recorded it, and took it to the top of of the country charts was Rosanne Cash –
